Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CalBug, an Interactive Database Using Arthropods to Examine Impacts of Climate Change and Habitat Modification
Award.AbstractNarration: Habitat modification and climate change are occurring at unprecedented rates globally. While tools to predict future environments have become increasingly sophisticated, there is little understanding of how biodiversity will respond to novel environments. The current proposal represents collaboration among eight entomological collections in California to digitize specimens and thus allow assessment of how distributions of organisms have been modified through environmental change. It makes use of a long history of entomological collecting in the state to develop a database of approximately 1 million georeferenced specimens collected at focal localities over the last century. The specimen data will be used in geospatial analyses to understand the relationship between the distribution of species and the type and extent of habitat modification. The project will serve as a model for integrating data across multiple institutions and incorporating the combined data within a geospatial framework. Human-driven environmental change has already caused huge impacts on biological systems. To understand how biodiversity will respond to environmental change in the future, we must learn from their responses in the past. A large amount of data is available on organisms that existed in environments before and after habitat modification over the last century; however, much of this information is hidden within museum collections, held on labels among millions of specimens. The proposed digitization and georeferencing of these collections will transform research capability and access to information by both scientists and the public. It will result in a fully georeferenced database of target taxa from natural reserves throughout California that will be searchable and available on web-accessible maps. The proposal includes entomological museums of all sizes and audiences in California and provides education of graduate and undergraduate students in taxonomy and systematic, coupled with the use of bioinformatics and geospatial modeling as applied to habitat modification and climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Habitat modification and climate change are occurring at unprecedented rates globally. While tools to predict future environments have become increasingly sophisticated, there is little understanding of how biodiversity will respond to novel environments. Our project was a collaboration among 8 entomological collections in California to digitize specimens and thus allow assessment of how their distributions have been modified through environmental change. It made use of a long history of entomological collecting in the state to develop a database of georeferenced specimens collected at focal localities over the last century. The specimen data was then used in geospatial analyses to understand the relationship between the distribution of species and the type and extent of habitat modification.

The project served as a model for integrating data across multiple institutions and incorporating the combined data within a geospatial framework. Besides digitizing, we focused on several aspects that expanded the reach of the effort: (1) We developed and tested methods and workflows to increase the rate of data capture, while maximizing data quality. (2) With collaborators, we developed a crowdsourcing initiative, the Notes from Nature (NfN), a citizen science transcription project. Calbug provided images of pinned insects and during the transcription process, citizen scientists received feedback about how many transcriptions they had performed and garnered badges for different kinds of activities. (3) We integrated the effort, which focused on several well-known sites in California, with interests of the UC Agriculture and Natural Resources (ANR) Research and Extension Centers (RECs), the UC Natural Reserve System (NRS) and Center for Forestry (CFF). In this way, we could capitalize on the long history of research at these sites, as reflected by the numerous specimens held at each. (4) We coordinated and leveraged the effort with parallel activities on campus that used museum collections to look at response to environmental change. In particular, we used Calbug as a source of data for a Keck-funded project to build an informatics tool for integrating biodiversity, ecological, and geospatial data from UC Berkeley’s labs, natural history museums, and field stations, and provide a mechanism for analyzing these disparate and complex data in the context of understanding global change biology. Specimen data from the historical and modern Calbug collections were incorporated into climate layers, together with additional site specific data, as available, to determine factors that might account for shifts in distributions of certain taxa. (5) The focus of the project has now grown such that we are working internationally to coordinate efforts and exploring synergies and sustainability for Biodiversity Information Systems.

Intellectual Merit: Human-driven environmental change has already caused huge impacts on biological systems. To understand how biodiversity will respond to environmental change in the future, we must learn from their responses in the past. A huge amount of data is available on organisms that existed in environments before and after habitat modification over the last century; however, much of this information is hidden within museum collections, held on labels among millions of specimens. By digitizing and georeferencing these collections we were able to make a large body of data available. By making us of crowdsourcing approaches, we were able to scale up the rate of data entry. And, by leveraging parallel efforts on campus, we were able to integrate the specimen data we generated with other data layers, and analyze the combined information in such a way as to transform research capability and make information accessible to both scientists and the public.

Broader Impacts: The project provided training for one postdoc, 5 graduate students and 26 undergraduate students in taxonomy and systematics coupled with the use of bioinformatics and geospatial modeling as applied to habitat modification and climate change. We were also able to engage the general public through the Noes from Nature citizen science online experience. In the process of the work, we made data accessible, and integrated this into an informatics pipeline that allowed us to examine how the environment is changing, and provide insights into the shifting spatial structure of California's natural resources.
